channel.title: jimgrisham tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from jimgrisham.

item.description:
@joshuadtitus @ibogost Indeed. (As virtualization becomes more accessible to the non-tech user, development will become easier for vast majority of desktop applications.)

Internet-based services have an enduring edge in anything that requires real-time collaboration, frequent updates, or mobility.

@joshuadtitus @ibogost Cloud computing has many advantages, but non-native clients/frontends for (especially non-touchscreen) desktop computers tend to:

  • foreclose many UI best practices (such as taking advantage of #FittsLaw/spatial consistency, multiple windows/pallets, and multiple screens)

1/3

@joshuadtitus @ibogost - more affect users with limited / less reliable connectivity or older hardware (especially after the well-intentioned shift to process isolation in web browsers)

  • create confusion over data portability and lessen user control over migration timelines

2/3

@joshuadtitus @ibogost Those last two affect poorer and smaller businesses the most and are less of a problem for large corporate clients; attention follows the money, ofc (as does rent-seeking).

Functional native clients with an optional ‘cloud’ backend will likely always be in demand for some.

3/3

@joshuadtitus @ibogost While listed ‘off the top of my head’, I included those specific ones due to personal knowledge of multiple people who currently use at least one of those nearly daily, by choice, at their homes or small businesses.

People use computers in sometimes vastly different ways.

@joshuadtitus @ibogost (yes, everything is going to have various ‘issues’ depending on the environment or ones requirements, if course, but the persistence of some archaic software also shows an unmet need in at least a few very specific circumstances)

@joshuadtitus @ibogost E-mail: Eudora, then Mulberry for the IMAP generation

PIM and media: Palm Desktop and iTunes

Desktop publishing: Photoshop, Freehand, and Acrobat

SMB in-house apps and databases: FileMaker Pro and Visual FoxPro

Typing: Nisus Writer, WordPerfect 5.1 for DOS
item.source:markdown:
@joshuadtitus @ibogost E-mail: Eudora, then Mulberry for the IMAP generation
PIM and media: Palm Desktop and iTunes
Desktop publishing: Photoshop, Freehand, and Acrobat
SMB in-house apps and databases: FileMaker Pro and Visual FoxPro
Typing: Nisus Writer, WordPerfect 5.1 for DOS

item.description:
@Yojimbo2049 @ibogost I mean, that’s partly because they’re not really ‘native’ apps.

They’re including a bloated ‘cross-platform framework’ (or an actual internal web browser) with each install, which explains why they are so slow and hungry for memory.
item.source:markdown:
@Yojimbo2049 @ibogost I mean, that’s partly because they’re not really ‘native’ apps.
They’re including a bloated ‘cross-platform framework’ (or an actual internal web browser) with each install, which explains why they are so slow and hungry for memory.

item.description: @gardengnome_au @ibogost Slack and Teams may exist as ‘desktop’ apps, but they’re not really ‘native desktop’ apps.
item.source:markdown: @gardengnome_au @ibogost Slack and Teams may exist as ‘desktop’ apps, but they’re not really ‘native desktop’ apps.

item.description:
@Caff3i3n3 @ibogost Even Google Drive (the installable version) is just a skinned version Chromium now!

It barely even requires a UI. Why… 😞
item.source:markdown:
@Caff3i3n3 @ibogost Even Google Drive (the installable version) is just a skinned version Chromium now!
It barely even requires a UI. Why… 😞

item.description:
@tonyrtoon @ibogost I bet that runs great in a Web ASM-backed in-browser emulator; once it’s running, there’s not even any network traffic!

How about a web emulator version of WP5 for DOS…

(the average JS browser tab uses far more RAM than systems running Word 5.1 would have had at the time)

@SarahEJoyal @timothyaclark @ibogost I was reading a design document from c. 1995 yesterday and a ‘unified inbox’ was all the rage back then (at the time, for: fax, e-mail, IM, voicemails, etc.).

BlackBerry tried again circa 2015 with their ‘Hub’, but everyone generally wants to stay all siloed for profit reasons.
item.source:markdown:
@SarahEJoyal @timothyaclark @ibogost I was reading a design document from c. 1995 yesterday and a ‘unified inbox’ was all the rage back then (at the time, for: fax, e-mail, IM, voicemails, etc.).
BlackBerry tried again circa 2015 with their ‘Hub’, but everyone generally wants to stay all siloed for profit reasons.

item.description:
@pamela_barone @rdrimmel The #Iridium network?

After the initial bankruptcy I believe they re-organized and currently provide service to governments and corporate clients.

(not sure if the first generation of satellites is still active, though)

@IridiumComm #leo #satcomm

@pamela_barone @rdrimmel @IridiumComm (780 km altitude, per the Twitter bio of @IridiumBoss)

@pamela_barone @rdrimmel The Iridium network?

After the initial bankruptcy I believe they re-organized and currently provide service to governments and corporate clients.

(not sure if the first generation of satellites is still active, though)

@Bensade @jonrog1 In fact, being wealthy (or becoming wealthy) is sometimes even seen as reason for not promoting / retaining someone, since they don’t need they job and thus are much less likely to quietly put up with exploitation or abuse.
item.source:markdown: @Bensade @jonrog1 In fact, being wealthy (or becoming wealthy) is sometimes even seen as reason for ~not~ promoting / retaining someone, since they don’t ~need~ they job and thus are much less likely to quietly put up with exploitation or abuse.

item.description:
Irony of the day, courtesy of @nngroup:

Jakob Nielsen’s March 1999 #Alertbox article extolling #persistentURLs, “URL as UI”, is no longer accessible at its original URL (https://t.co/c4sm8YIhdd).

To be fair, it did work for over 20 years, which is much better than average!

@NNgroup FYI: Discovered since it is hyperlinked near the end of the “Cool URIs don't change" section of @timberners_lee’s “Style Guide for online hypertext” (https://t.co/bwNYfKV9aZ), currently hosted by the @W3C.

(I imagine the old link will start working again by the end of the week)

Note: The #Alertbox article itself is still live and can be read at: https://t.co/g0G7VH0wUJ
item.source:markdown:

Jakob Nielsen’s March 1999 #Alertbox article extolling #persistentURLs, “URL as UI”, is no longer accessible at its original URL (https://t.co/c4sm8YIhdd).
To be fair, it did work for over 20 years, which is ~much~ better than average!
@NNgroup FYI: Discovered since it is hyperlinked near the end of the “Cool URIs don't change" section of @timberners_lee’s “Style Guide for online hypertext” (https://t.co/bwNYfKV9aZ), currently hosted by the @W3C.
(I imagine the old link will start working again by the end of the week)

item.description:
@markproxy @evernote Wait, it’s 2022 and @Evernote can’t do that yet?!

- - -

It’s too bad @ScrivenerApp doesn’t have an Android version yet (and the workarounds[1][2] don’t support auto-linking notes).

@SimpleNoteApp does, though.

[1] https://t.co/cAYWtrbpgw [2] https://t.co/tJMssqlDe4
@pizzafruittart @FPWellman https://t.co/TX7yOD7E1p
item.source:markdown: @pizzafruittart @FPWellman https://t.co/TX7yOD7E1p

item.description:
@KayYash6 @1sweetlyfierce1 @allbusch @Angry_Staffer Pretty much.

10 CFR includes most energy-related regulations, except for conservation (18 CFR) and mining (30 CFR).

 - - -

CFR: Title 10. Energy: https://t.co/11aPOhkXzG

@KayYash6 @1sweetlyfierce1 @allbusch @Angry_Staffer Laws regarding energy-related topics seem to be mostly found in various chapters of Title 42 of the United States Code: https://t.co/aJHITbXKOH

(e.g. 42 U.S.C. chapters 14, 23, 24, 71, 73, 74, 81, 83, 84, 91, 93, 94, 96, 98–101, 125, 134, 149, 152, 161, & 162)
@GorillaMurphy @MuellerSheWrote How did he ‘work’ out of there for 4 years without someone building an on-site SCIF?
item.source:markdown: @GorillaMurphy @MuellerSheWrote How did he ‘work’ out of there for 4 years without someone building an on-site SCIF?

item.description: @paulcomp @Adlemig @Tupp_Ed A recent survey found that a significant fraction of younger Americans thought that using a standard aerial antenna to watch live TV broadcasts was a form of #piracy.
item.source:markdown: @paulcomp @Adlemig @Tupp_Ed A recent survey found that a significant fraction of younger Americans thought that using a standard aerial antenna to watch live TV broadcasts was a form of #piracy.

item.description: @DerekL1963 @Casillic It could be manually cleaned (with the cleaning materials placed into the outgoing container) as necessary, and then scanned for surface contamination while still within the glovebox.
item.source:markdown: @DerekL1963 @Casillic It could be manually cleaned (with the cleaning materials placed into the outgoing container) as necessary, and then scanned for surface contamination while still within the glovebox.

item.description:
@1sweetlyfierce1 @allbusch @Angry_Staffer Much of that is considered “Restricted Data”, under terms of the “Atomic Energy Act of 1954” (first established under the “the Atomic Energy Act of 1946”).

https://t.co/DXnRAffRU8

@1sweetlyfierce1 @allbusch @Angry_Staffer See also 10 CFR 1045, “Nuclear Classification and Declassification”

Quick training summary: https://t.co/rexYpAPhDE

@1sweetlyfierce1 @allbusch @Angry_Staffer For those playing along at home, those #RestrictedData definitions refer to the term of art “Special Nuclear Material”.

 - - -

#SpecialNuclearMaterial is separately defined at: https://t.co/9K8vSBVUR3

@CitrineGlitter @Bask1983 @elisabethbraw @PhillipsPOBrien One report claimed it was feed corn intended for raising chickens… I imagine they have more immediate needs of human-ready grains at the moment.
item.source:markdown: @CitrineGlitter @Bask1983 @elisabethbraw @PhillipsPOBrien One report claimed it was feed corn intended for raising chickens… I imagine they have more immediate needs of human-ready grains at the moment.
